metadata.subject: physics
metadata.topicName: Single Photon and Electron Double Slit Experiments
metadata.dotPoint: interpret the single photon and the electron double slit experiment as evidence for the dual nature of light and matter

single_photon_setup.name: Single Photon Experiment Setup
single_photon_setup.formula: One photon at a time through slits
single_photon_setup.correct: In the single photon experiment, light intensity is reduced so only one photon passes through the double slits at any time.

many photons at once.error: That describes Young's original experiment, not the single photon version.
many photons at once.fix: The key feature is extreme low intensity so only ONE photon is in flight at a time.
many photons at once.action: Compare: Young's experiment uses continuous beams; single photon uses one-at-a-time detection.

electrons instead of photons.error: You're confusing the photon and electron versions of the experiment.
electrons instead of photons.fix: The single photon experiment uses light (photons). There's a separate electron version.
electrons instead of photons.action: Keep them distinct: photon version proves dual nature of light, electron version proves dual nature of matter.

high intensity light.error: High intensity means many photons, defeating the purpose.
high intensity light.fix: Very faint light ensures only one photon is present at any time.
high intensity light.action: Think: why would we need low intensity? To isolate individual particle behavior.

persistent.gap: You don't understand why single-particle detection is crucial.
persistent.action: The experiment proves each particle interferes with ITSELF. Multiple particles would allow particle-particle interference.

photon_interference_pattern.name: Single Photon Interference Pattern
photon_interference_pattern.formula: Pattern builds up spot by spot
photon_interference_pattern.correct: Individual photons each create a single spot on the detector, but over time these spots form the same interference pattern as continuous light.

each photon creates a full pattern.error: A single photon creates only ONE spot, not a pattern.
each photon creates a full pattern.fix: The pattern emerges statistically from many individual detection events.
each photon creates a full pattern.action: Imagine: one photon = one spot. Thousands of photons = pattern of spots.

no pattern forms.error: The interference pattern definitely forms, just gradually.
no pattern forms.fix: As more photons arrive, the spots accumulate into the classic interference pattern.
no pattern forms.action: Look at the buildup images: random-looking at first, clear bands after many detections.

spots form two bands only.error: That would be particle-only behavior (no interference).
spots form two bands only.fix: An interference pattern has multiple bright and dark bands, not just two.
spots form two bands only.action: Two bands = particles going through one slit or the other. Many bands = wave interference.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding how the pattern builds up statistically.
persistent.action: Study the progression images showing pattern formation from 10 to 10,000 photons.

photon_self_interference.name: Photon Self-Interference
photon_self_interference.correct: Since only one photon is present at a time, the interference pattern implies each photon passes through both slits simultaneously and interferes with itself.

photons interfere with each other.error: With only one photon at a time, there's nothing else to interfere with.
photons interfere with each other.fix: Self-interference: each photon somehow samples both paths.
photons interfere with each other.action: Ask: if only one photon exists, what is it interfering with? Itself.

photons avoid the dark regions randomly.error: Random avoidance wouldn't produce regular interference bands.
photons avoid the dark regions randomly.fix: The pattern is systematic, indicating wave behavior guiding where photons land.
photons avoid the dark regions randomly.action: Randomness would produce uniform distribution. Bands require wave interference.

detectors create the pattern.error: The detector just records where photons land; it doesn't influence their paths.
detectors create the pattern.fix: The wave nature of the photon determines the probability of where it will be detected.
detectors create the pattern.action: Detectors are passive recorders, not pattern creators.

persistent.gap: You're not accepting the counterintuitive nature of quantum behavior.
persistent.action: The photon exists as a probability wave until detected. It explores all paths simultaneously.

which_path_detection.name: Which-Path Detection Effect
which_path_detection.correct: If detectors are placed to determine which slit a photon passes through, the interference pattern disappears and only two bands form.

interference pattern remains.error: Measuring which path destroys the wave behavior.
interference pattern remains.fix: When you know the path, the photon behaves as a particle, not a wave.
interference pattern remains.action: This is the complementarity principle: wave OR particle behavior, not both simultaneously observed.

photon is detected at both slits.error: Each photon is only ever detected at ONE slit.
photon is detected at both slits.fix: Particle-like detection means one slit OR the other, never both.
photon is detected at both slits.action: Wave nature: explores both paths. Particle nature: detected at only one.

pattern becomes more defined.error: Opposite: the interference pattern vanishes entirely.
pattern becomes more defined.fix: Knowing the path forces particle behavior, eliminating wave interference.
pattern becomes more defined.action: Observation changes the outcome—a key quantum principle.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how measurement affects quantum systems.
persistent.action: Study the complementarity principle: measuring wave property destroys particle information and vice versa.

electron_double_slit.name: Single Electron Double Slit
electron_double_slit.formula: Electrons one at a time through slits
electron_double_slit.correct: When single electrons are sent through a double slit, they produce individual spots that gradually build up into an interference pattern.

electrons pass through in groups.error: The key feature is single-electron detection.
electrons pass through in groups.fix: Like photons, electrons are sent one at a time to prove self-interference.
electrons pass through in groups.action: Same logic: one particle at a time eliminates particle-particle interference.

electrons produce continuous bands immed.error: Like photons, individual electrons create discrete spots.
electrons produce continuous bands immed.fix: Each electron is detected as a particle (single spot), but the pattern emerges statistically.
electrons produce continuous bands immed.action: Electrons show particle behavior on detection but wave behavior in path selection.

no interference pattern forms.error: The interference pattern definitely forms, confirming electron wave nature.
no interference pattern forms.fix: Electrons diffract and interfere just like photons, proving matter has wave properties.

persistent.gap: You're not accepting that matter exhibits wave behavior.
persistent.action: The electron experiments prove de Broglie was right: all matter has wave properties.

electron_wave_behavior.name: Electron Wave-Particle Evidence
electron_wave_behavior.correct: The electron double slit experiment provides evidence that electrons exhibit wave properties (diffraction, interference) despite being particles with mass.

proves electrons are purely waves.error: Each electron is detected as a discrete particle—wave properties alone can't explain detection.
proves electrons are purely waves.fix: Electrons show BOTH wave and particle behavior, hence 'wave-particle duality'.
proves electrons are purely waves.action: Dual nature: wave behavior in propagation, particle behavior on detection.

proves electrons are purely particles.error: Pure particles wouldn't produce interference patterns.
proves electrons are purely particles.fix: The interference pattern is wave behavior; the discrete detection is particle behavior.
proves electrons are purely particles.action: Two bands = particle only. Multiple interference bands = wave nature required.

only works for high-energy electrons.error: Wave behavior occurs at all electron energies, though wavelength varies.
only works for high-energy electrons.fix: de Broglie wavelength λ = h/p works for any momentum.
only works for high-energy electrons.action: Higher energy = smaller wavelength, but wave nature is always present.

persistent.gap: You're trying to classify electrons as purely one thing or another.
persistent.action: Accept duality: electrons ARE both wave and particle. Neither description alone is complete.

particle_detection_discrete.name: Discrete Particle Detection
particle_detection_discrete.correct: Both photons and electrons are detected as individual particles, creating discrete spots on the detector screen.

particles spread across the screen.error: Each detection event is a single localized spot.
particles spread across the screen.fix: Particle property: detection is always discrete and localized.
particles spread across the screen.action: Wave behavior determines WHERE the particle might land; particle behavior determines HOW it lands (one spot).

particles create wave patterns directly.error: Individual particles don't create patterns—the statistical accumulation does.
particles create wave patterns directly.fix: One particle = one spot. Many particles = pattern of spots forming interference bands.
particles create wave patterns directly.action: Distinguish: wave guides probability, particle creates the actual detection event.

multiple spots per particle.error: Each photon or electron creates exactly ONE detection event.
multiple spots per particle.fix: One particle, one spot. This is the particle aspect of the duality.
multiple spots per particle.action: If one particle made multiple spots, we wouldn't observe discrete detection.

persistent.gap: You're confusing the wave probability distribution with particle detection.
persistent.action: Wave = probability of where. Particle = discrete event when detected.

wave_probability_distribution.name: Wave Probability Distribution
wave_probability_distribution.correct: The wave nature of particles determines the probability distribution of where particles will be detected, creating the interference pattern.

wave determines exact landing position.error: The wave gives probabilities, not exact positions.
wave determines exact landing position.fix: Each individual detection is random within the probability distribution.
wave determines exact landing position.action: Many particles are needed to reveal the probability pattern.

probability is uniform across screen.error: Uniform probability would mean no interference pattern.
probability is uniform across screen.fix: Wave interference creates high probability (bright bands) and low probability (dark bands).
probability is uniform across screen.action: Interference = non-uniform probability. Bright = high probability. Dark = low probability.

particles follow classical trajectories.error: Classical trajectories can't explain interference from two slits.
particles follow classical trajectories.fix: The wave function explores all paths; this is fundamentally non-classical.
particles follow classical trajectories.action: Classical: particle goes through one slit. Quantum: wave goes through both.

persistent.gap: You're applying classical thinking to quantum phenomena.
persistent.action: Probability waves are fundamentally different from classical trajectories. Embrace the weirdness.

dual_nature_light.name: Dual Nature of Light
dual_nature_light.formula: Light shows wave and particle properties
dual_nature_light.correct: The single photon double slit experiment proves light has a dual nature: wave properties (interference pattern) and particle properties (discrete detection).

only wave nature proven.error: The discrete detection of individual photons proves particle nature.
only wave nature proven.fix: Interference = wave nature. One spot per photon = particle nature. Both observed.
only wave nature proven.action: Young's experiment only showed waves. Single-photon adds particle evidence.

only particle nature proven.error: The interference pattern proves wave nature.
only particle nature proven.fix: If photons were only particles, we'd see two bands, not interference bands.
only particle nature proven.action: Particle-only would mean: left slit → left band, right slit → right band.

dual nature is just an approximation.error: Dual nature is fundamental to quantum physics, not an approximation.
dual nature is just an approximation.fix: Wave-particle duality is the correct description of quantum objects.
dual nature is just an approximation.action: It's not that we don't understand fully—duality IS the full picture.

persistent.gap: You're trying to reduce light to just one classical category.
persistent.action: Light is neither purely wave nor purely particle. It's a quantum object with both properties.

dual_nature_matter.name: Dual Nature of Matter
dual_nature_matter.formula: Matter shows wave and particle properties
dual_nature_matter.correct: The single electron double slit experiment proves matter has a dual nature: wave properties (interference pattern) and particle properties (discrete detection).

only applies to electrons.error: Experiments show wave behavior for neutrons, atoms, and molecules too.
only applies to electrons.fix: All matter exhibits wave-particle duality, not just electrons.
only applies to electrons.action: de Broglie wavelength applies to everything: λ = h/p is universal.

matter is fundamentally different from l.error: Both light and matter show wave-particle duality.
matter is fundamentally different from l.fix: The symmetry is remarkable: both exhibit the same dual nature.
matter is fundamentally different from l.action: This unification was a major insight of quantum physics.

wave behavior is only for small particle.error: All matter has a de Broglie wavelength; large objects just have immeasurably small wavelengths.
wave behavior is only for small particle.fix: Large mass → large momentum → tiny wavelength → undetectable wave behavior.
wave behavior is only for small particle.action: Calculate: a baseball's wavelength is about 10⁻³⁴ m—far too small to observe.

persistent.gap: You're limiting wave-particle duality to special cases.
persistent.action: Duality is universal. The formulas apply to everything from photons to bowling balls.

young_vs_single_photon.name: Young's vs Single Photon Experiment
young_vs_single_photon.correct: Young's experiment shows light's wave nature; the single photon experiment additionally shows particle nature, proving dual nature.

they prove the same thing.error: Young's only proves wave nature. Single photon adds particle evidence.
they prove the same thing.fix: Young's: continuous wave interference. Single photon: discrete particles forming wave pattern.
they prove the same thing.action: Key addition: individual detection events prove photons are also particles.

single photon experiment replaces Young'.error: Both experiments are valid and complementary.
single photon experiment replaces Young'.fix: Young's showed waves; single photon showed that waves are made of discrete particles.
single photon experiment replaces Young'.action: Historical progression: wave model → particle discovery → wave-particle duality.

Young's experiment shows particle nature.error: Young's continuous beam doesn't reveal discrete particle detection.
Young's experiment shows particle nature.fix: With continuous light, you can't isolate individual photon behavior.
Young's experiment shows particle nature.action: Single photon experiment was specifically designed to test individual particle behavior.

persistent.action: Make a comparison table: what each experiment shows about wave vs particle nature.

interference_requires_both_slits.name: Both Slits Required for Interference
interference_requires_both_slits.correct: Interference occurs because the wave aspect of each particle passes through both slits simultaneously, then interferes with itself.

particle chooses one slit randomly.error: Random single-slit passage wouldn't produce interference, just two bands.
particle chooses one slit randomly.fix: The wave function goes through BOTH slits; the particle appears at one location on detection.
particle chooses one slit randomly.action: Block one slit: interference disappears. Both slits needed for self-interference.

particles from both slits interfere with.error: With single particles, there's nothing else to interfere with.
particles from both slits interfere with.fix: Each particle's wave function interferes with ITSELF via both paths.
particles from both slits interfere with.action: One particle at a time = self-interference only.

interference happens after detection.error: Interference determines the probability BEFORE detection.
interference happens after detection.fix: Wave interference → probability distribution → particle detected according to that distribution.

persistent.action: Until detected, the particle exists in a superposition of going through both slits.

d4.tooltip: What pattern emerges from wave behavior?

single_electron.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate understanding of how single electrons behave in double slit experiments.

d2.tooltip: Individual localized detection shows which nature?

sentences.text: Over many detection events, the individual electron spots accumulate to form an {{d3}}, demonstrating that electrons also possess {{d4}} properties.

d3.tooltip: What pattern emerges from wave behavior?

d4.tooltip: Interference is a property of what?

sentences.text: The electron double slit experiment was first successfully performed by Claus Jönsson in {{d5}}, and later confirmed with single electrons, providing strong evidence for {{d6}} of matter.

d6.tooltip: What fundamental quantum principle was demonstrated?

dual_nature_evidence.title: Evidence for Wave-Particle Duality
dual_nature_evidence.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to synthesize the evidence for the dual nature of light and matter.

sentences.text: Young's original double slit experiment demonstrated the {{d1}} of light, but the single photon experiment additionally proves {{d2}} by showing discrete detection events.

d1.tooltip: What did Young's continuous beam show?

d2.tooltip: What does individual photon detection demonstrate?

sentences.text: The wave aspect of particles determines the {{d3}} of where detection will occur, while the particle aspect ensures that detection always occurs at a {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Waves don't determine exact positions, they determine...?

d4.tooltip: How do particles appear when detected?

sentences.text: Both single photon and single electron experiments demonstrate that quantum objects exhibit {{d5}} depending on the type of measurement, which is the essence of {{d6}}.

single_photon.title: Interpreting Single Photon Behavior
single_photon.instructions: Apply your understanding of single photon experiments to these scenarios.

d1.tooltip: What does a single photon create upon detection?

d2.tooltip: What pattern emerges statistically from wave behavior?

sentences.text: When detectors are placed to identify which slit each photon passes through, the interference pattern {{d3}} and is replaced by {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What happens to wave behavior when particle path is measured?

d4.correct: two bands corresponding to each slit
d4.tooltip: What pattern does pure particle behavior produce?

sentences.text: This demonstrates the complementarity principle: measuring {{d5}} properties destroys the {{d6}} behavior, and vice versa.

d5.tooltip: Which-path detection measures which type of property?

d6.tooltip: Interference is a property of which behavior?

single_electron.title: Interpreting Single Electron Behavior
single_electron.instructions: Apply your understanding of single electron experiments to these scenarios.

sentences.text: Like photons, electrons exhibit wave-particle duality because each electron is detected as a {{d1}}, but the statistical pattern of many electrons shows {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: How does each individual electron appear?

d2.tooltip: What does the accumulated pattern demonstrate?

sentences.text: The interference pattern for electrons requires that each electron's {{d3}} passes through both slits, even though the electron is ultimately detected at {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What mathematical description goes through both slits?

d4.tooltip: Where is the electron actually detected?

sentences.text: This experiment proves that de Broglie was correct: matter with {{d5}} also has an associated {{d6}} that determines its wave behavior.

d6.tooltip: What wave property did de Broglie predict for matter?

dual_nature_evidence.title: Synthesizing Evidence for Duality
dual_nature_evidence.instructions: Apply your understanding to connect the photon and electron experiments.

sentences.text: The parallel between photon and electron experiments is striking: both show {{d1}} on individual detection but {{d2}} in statistical accumulation.

d2.tooltip: The interference pattern reveals which nature?

sentences.text: The key evidence that particles interfere with themselves rather than each other is that {{d3}} creates a pattern when {{d4}} are accumulated.

d3.correct: sending particles one at a time

d4.tooltip: What accumulates to reveal the pattern?

sentences.text: Wave-particle duality is not a failure to understand quantum objects; it is the {{d5}} description of their behavior, applying to {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Is duality a limitation or the truth?

single_photon.title: Mastery of Single Photon Concepts
single_photon.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of single photon double slit experiments.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that Young's double slit experiment shows wave-particle duality. In fact, Young's experiment only demonstrates {{d1}} because it uses a {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: Why can't Young's experiment show particle nature?

sentences.text: The single photon experiment resolves the paradox of wave-particle duality by showing that the wave function describes {{d3}} while particle detection is the {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: What does the wave function actually describe?

d4.tooltip: What is the particle detection event?

sentences.text: When physicists say a photon goes through both slits, they mean its {{d5}} samples both paths, not that the photon is physically in two places, which is why detection always finds {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: What mathematical entity goes through both slits?

d6.correct: one whole photon at one location
distractors: half a photon at each slit
the photon spread across the screen
d6.tooltip: What is always found upon detection?

single_electron.title: Mastery of Single Electron Concepts
single_electron.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of single electron double slit experiments.

sentences.text: The single electron experiment disproves the idea that electrons are tiny classical particles because classical particles would produce {{d1}}, not {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What would purely classical particles create?

sentences.text: Unlike photons, electrons have {{d3}}, yet both exhibit identical wave-particle duality, proving that duality is not limited to {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: Photons are massless; is duality limited to them?

sentences.text: The wavelength of matter is related to momentum by λ = h/p, explaining why everyday objects don't show obvious wave behavior: their {{d5}} gives them {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Large mass times any velocity gives what?

d6.tooltip: What happens to λ when p is very large?

dual_nature_evidence.title: Complete Evidence Synthesis
dual_nature_evidence.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by connecting all aspects of wave-particle duality evidence.

d1.tooltip: How must particles be sent to prove self-interference?

d2.tooltip: What property of each individual particle causes interference?

sentences.text: Both photon and electron experiments show the same fundamental behavior: {{d3}} determines where particles are likely to land, but {{d4}} governs how they appear when detected.

d4.tooltip: What ensures each detection is a single spot?

sentences.text: The experiments prove that wave-particle duality is {{d5}} of all quantum objects, and that the classical distinction between waves and particles {{d6}} at the quantum scale.

d5.tooltip: Is duality inherent or just apparent?
